qas.question: Why couldn't Asa Gray use a Boston publisher for an American version of On the Origin of Species?

answers.text: two New York publishing firms were already planning to exploit the absence of international copyright to print Origin

qas.question: How much of a royalty was Gray able to negotiate with a New York publisher for On the Origin of Species?
When was the first American edition of On the Origin of Species published?
What did Darwin decide to do with the profits of the American version of On the Origin of Species?

answers.text: asked Gray to keep any profits

qas.question: What was the print run that Darwin mentioned for On the Origin of Species?

context: In the United States, botanist Asa Gray an American colleague of Darwin negotiated with a Boston publisher for publication of an authorised American version, but learnt that <a0_0>two New York publishing firms were already planning to exploit the absence of international copyright to print Origin<a0_0/>. Darwin was delighted by the popularity of the book, and <a3_0>asked Gray to keep any profits<a3_0/>. Gray managed to negotiate <a1_0>a 5% royalty<a1_0/> with Appleton's of New York, who got their edition out in <a2_0>mid January 1860<a2_0/>, and the other two withdrew. In a May letter, Darwin mentioned a print run of <a4_0>2,500 copies<a4_0/>, but it is not clear if this referred to the first printing only as there were four that year.
